title: EPA Method 22 - Observing the Frequency of Visible Emissions

sections.title: EPA Method 22 - Observing the Frequency of Visible Emissions

content.text:
US EPA Test Method 22 is used to determine the frequency of visible emissions from fugitive sources and flares. Opacity is not determined using Method 22 - only the presence or absence of visible emissions.

Method 22 can be used for the following applications:
 • Visible emissions which cross a property boundary.
 • Flares used for the combustion of natural gas and other gaseous waste.
 • Visible emissions which escape a building which are not vented and collected.
 • Visible emissions inside a building which are not vented and collected.

columns.text: Gas flares usually burn clean but may have visible emissions if not functioning correctly.
Method 22 can be used to observe the frequency of visible emissions inside or outside a building.

content.text:
Method 22 simply determines whether emissions are present or absent. Method 9 determines the opacity of the emissions present. Some sources can have both a Method 22 and Method 9 testing requirement on the same source. For example: If a Method 22 test detects visible emissions, the test may stop and a Method 9 test may be initiated to determine the opacity of the emissions.

Method 22 recommends completing a smoke school lecture course and at least one visual test. However, there is no certification requirement for Method 22.
